doc.title: India: 50% non-fossil power capacity achieved and what's next for India's energy transition
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-28/Sustainable Investing India 50 non-fossil power capacity achieved and whats next for Indias energy transitionSustainable_2025-08-28

passages.text: Sustainable Investing

India reached 50% non- fossil power capacity in July 2025, five years ahead of its 2030 target. We see room to improve this target, with China having set 70% by 2030. We also highlight key opportunities and challenges for India to reach its other energy transition target, 500GW renewables by 2030.

India has two major energy transition targets to be achieved by 2030: to reach 50% non- fossil fuel power capacity, and to build 500GW of renewables capacity. With green power investment outpacing thermal power in recent years, India achieved the first target in July 2025, based on recent data releases.

Further room for target improvement: India's first target reach is consistent with our expectations as the country had already achieved 47% non- fossil fuel power generating capacity at the end of 2024. At the same time, China's more ambitious target (70% by 2030) suggests room for India to set a new and higher target. For the 500GW renewables target by 2030, India will need to accelerate the pace of annual power capacity additions to 48GW per annum during 2025- 2030, compared with the less than 30GW pa added in the past few years. On the positive side, renewables capacity added in the first seven months of 2025 was already higher than for the whole of 2024.

This document is intended for institutional investors and is not subject to all of the independence and disclosure standards applicable to debt research reports prepared for retail investors under U.S. FINRA Rule 2242. Barclays trades the securities covered in this report for its own account and on a discretionary basis on behalf of certain clients. Such trading interests may be contrary to the recommendations offered in this report.
This research report has been prepared in whole or in part by equity research analysts based outside the US who are not registered/qualified as research analysts with FINRA.

This author is a debt research analyst in the Fixed Income, Currencies and Commodities Research department and is neither an equity research analyst nor subject to all of the independence and disclosure standards applicable to analysts who produce debt research reports under U.S. FINRA Rule 2242.
This author is a member of the EMEA Equity Research department who may publish equity and debt research
FOR ANALYST CERTIFICATION(S) PLEASE SEE PAGE 7.
FOR IMPORTANT EQUITY RESEARCH DISCLOSURES, PLEASE SEE PAGE 7.
FOR IMPORTANT FIXED INCOME RESEARCH DISCLOSURES, PLEASE SEE PAGE 8. Completed: 27- Aug- 25, 07:50 GMT Released: 28- Aug- 25, 03:00 GMT Restricted - External

Key opportunities: While we are positive about India's energy transition opportunities, it faces several key challenges. In a recent report, we discussed the opportunities and obstacles that lie ahead, drawing insights from the achievements and lessons learned in China, the world's largest GHG emitter as well as a green solutions powerhouse. With sustained policy backing and continued capacity planning and investment, we estimate that India could scale up its installed power capacity for solar by \(110\%\) , wind by \(185\%\) , and nuclear by \(107\%\) by 2030.

Key challenges: India's key challenges include the scaling up of its gas- fired power capacity, which is complicated by much higher generation costs. India has also not committed to a coal exit timeline, which highlights its continuing dependence on this power source. Expanding renewables also requires significant investments in the power grid. We also highlight the recent introduction of a domestic carbon market, which excluded the power sector from the first phase.

India is Asia's second- largest renewable energy market after China, having added 27.9 GW of capacity in 2024 and 29.5 GW in January- July 2025 (+69.5% y/y). These additions powered a 9.2% rise in the country's non- fossil capacity mix versus 2022, led by solar and wind, with modest contributions from nuclear and large hydro (Figure 1). As of July 2025, India's non- fossil power generating capacity totalled 242.8 GW, up from 162.7 GW in 2022, the year India submitted its updated NDC target of \(50\%\) national electricity generation from non- fossil based sources1.

India and China had comparable non- fossil shares a decade ago, at \(32\%\) and \(33\%\) , respectively. Since then, China has expanded its share by 24 percentage points, outpacing India's 15pp increase (Figure 2). The resulting 10pp gap is largely due to faster solar and wind additions in China, while nuclear and large hydro contributions remained subdued in both countries (Figure 3). Given that India has already reached its \(50\%\) non- fossil power target and China plans to achieve \(70\%\) by 2030, we see room for India to set a new and higher target.
FIGURE 1. Change in installed capacity mix, 2022 vs Jan-Jul 2025
Source: Ministry of New and Renewable Energy, Barclays Research
FIGURE 2. China's green electricity transition proceeded faster than India's over the past decade
Source: BP Energy Statistics, Barclays Research

Setting a comparable target to China could also accelerate India's progress to achieve its target for 500GW of renewables capacity by 2030. India's annual renewable capacity additions pace have historically been below 30GW, though there has been a notable acceleration over Jan- Jul 2025, when more capacity was added than in full- year 2024. To meet the 2030 target of 500GW, the pace of additions will need to accelerate to 48GW annually. Even assuming a timeline extension to 2031- 32, we estimate that annual additions would still need to total 36- 41GW, significantly above historical norms and necessitating a rapid scale- up in execution (Figure 4).
FIGURE 3. Power capacity mix change by fuel type, 2014-2024
Source: BP Energy Statistics, Barclays Research
FIGURE 4. Annual renewable energy addition in different timeline scenarios of 2025-2030, 2025-2031 and 2025-32
Calculated based on December year-end Source: Barclays Research

As outlined in India's energy transition playbook: Drawing lessons from China (22 May 2025), we see strong potential and emerging opportunities across India's solar, wind, and nuclear sectors as part of India's energy transition. Key highlights for each are summarised below:

- Solar: India's favourable policy environment remains highly supportive of solar farm capacity additions and equipment manufacturing expansion. The expansion has been led by modules, which has also opened up the export business. We see scope for India to expand other components of the supply chain, such as cells, with upcoming incentives.

- Wind: India's wind power growth has fallen behind solar in the past several years, but has the potential to accelerate, supported by a more established manufacturing base and new offshore wind tenders. However, local manufacturing may face pricing pressure from low-cost Chinese turbines, despite growing focus on product degradation under Indian weather conditions.

- Nuclear: Nuclear is India's latest addition to its green transition framework, bolstered by accelerating plant approvals, a clear technology roadmap and expected private sector participation. In India: quick take on sustainability progress from 2025-2026 union budget (4 February 2025), we highlighted the importance of nuclear energy to achieve India's low-carbon transition targets by 2047.
FIGURE 5. India: Growth in solar demand has outpaced supply expansion
Source:BNEF,Barclays Research
FIGURE 6. Asia: Capacity growth forecasts for nuclear power capacity by 2030
Source:World Nuclear Association,Barclays Research

Despite the above opportunities, we continue to monitor the challenges India is facing in its energy transition, including continued expansion of coal power, underinvestment and slower execution in power transmission networks, and increasing absolute emissions.

- Coal continues to expand: India and China led global coal expansion in 2024, adding 5.8GW and 30.5GW, respectively, \(82\%\) of global of power capacity additions from this source (Figure 7). With 204GW (China) and 29.5GW (India) of coal capacity under construction, it is clear that neither nation plans to phase out coal. India's rising power demand, driven by GDP growth and low per-capita energy use, prompted a target of a minimum of 80GW of new coal capacity by 2031-32, which represents an almost tripling the current pace, keeping coal central to India's energy future.

- Power grid bottleneck: To meet its 500GW renewables goal, we estimate that India needs INR2.4trn of investment and the construction of 50,890 km of transmission lines, as detailed in India budget: power grid investment to support decarbonization (2 August 2024). But state-level execution has lagged (Figure 8), causing renewable curtailments and grid congestion, as flagged by NSEFI3. As a result, he non-fossil share in power generation has stagnated4, requiring sustained grid investment and execution to get back on track to meet targets.
FIGURE 7. China and India have added new coal power capacity every year since 2000
Source: Global Energy Monitor, Barclays Research
FIGURE 8. India's annual progress by state sector transmission, planned vs achieved
In CKM Source: Niti Aayog, Barclays Research

- The domestic carbon market excludes power, for now: India's national emissions trading system, the Carbon Credit Trading Scheme (CCTS), began with policy discussions in 2021 and was legally backed by the Energy Conservation Act in 2022. The Ministry of Power officially launched the CCTS in June 2023, and by July 2024, detailed compliance regulations were adopted, using an intensity-based baseline-and-credit system for nine energy-intensive sectors including Iron & Steel, Cement, Aluminium, Petrochem, Textile, Pulp & Paper, Petro refinery and Chloralkali. However, India's largest sector by emissions, power, is excluded from the first phase of the scheme.

Sustainable Investing Related Research: There is currently no globally accepted framework or definition (legal, regulatory or otherwise) of, nor market consensus as to what constitutes a 'sustainable', 'ESG', 'green', 'climate- friendly' or an equivalent company, investment, strategy or consideration or what precise attributes are required to be eligible to be categorised by such terms. This means there are different ways to evaluate a company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.

Any information, data, image, or other content including from a third party source contained, referred to herein or used for whatsoever purpose by Barclays or a third party ("Information"), in relation to any actual or potential 'ESG', 'sustainable' or equivalent objective, issue, factor or consideration is not intended to be relied upon for ESG or sustainability classification, regulatory regime or industry initiative purposes ("ESG Regimes"), unless otherwise stated. Nothing in these materials, including any images included therein, is intended to convey, suggest or indicate that Barclays considers or represents any product, service, person or body mentioned in these materials as meeting or qualifying for any ESG or sustainability classification, label or similar standards that may exist under ESG Regimes. Barclays has not conducted any assessment of compliance with ESG Regimes. Parties are reminded to make their own assessments for these purposes.
